conclusion: Determine the initial velocity of the shadow of the ball on the wall when the ball is thrown vertically upward.
The setup involves a point light source, a ball, and a wall, with the ball being thrown from the midpoint between the light source and the wall.
The ball is thrown vertically upward from a point that is equidistant from the light source and the wall.
Denote the distance from the light source to the ball (and also from the ball to the wall) as d.
The ball is thrown vertically upward with an initial velocity v_0.
The vertical position of the ball as a function of time t is given by y(t) = v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2.
y(t) is the height of the ball above the initial position, v_0 is the initial velocity, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The shadow of the ball on the wall is formed by the light rays from the point light source.
As the ball moves vertically, the shadow will move horizontally along the wall.
Using similar triangles, the horizontal position of the shadow x_s(t) on the wall can be related to the vertical position of the ball y(t).
Consider the triangle formed by the light source, the ball, and the shadow on the wall. The height of the triangle is y(t), and the base is d + x_s(t).
The similar triangle formed by the light source, the initial position of the ball, and the wall has a height of 0 and a base of d.
By the property of similar triangles, we have y(t)/(d + x_s(t)) = 0/d.
Differentiate x_s(t) with respect to time to find the velocity of the shadow v_s(t).
The derivative of y(t) with respect to time is dy(t)/dt = v_0 - gt.
Substituting this into the expression for v_s(t), we get v_s(t) = (d/(v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2)^2) * (v_0 - gt).
